column5: Response

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; SOCIAL SECURITY Office of the Commissioner April 25, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO: Bruce Reed Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy SUBJECT: Proposed Legislation Regarding Nazi War criminals
column5: The text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it consists of factual material related to proposed legislation, which is not considered privileged or deliberative information. In fact, the FOIA specifically exempts from protection "factual or purely factual material" (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(3)). ; ; There is no need to cite case law to support this conclusion, as the language of the FOIA itself is clear on this point. However, courts have consistently held that Exemption 5 does not apply to purely factual information, even if it is contained within a privileged document (see, e.g., Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980)).

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; I must convey to you in the strongest possible terms that we should proceed to introduce  legislation that will deny Social Security benefits to all Nazi war criminals who are denaturalized · on the basis of having participated in Nazi persecution. Currently, Nazi war criminals who have  been denaturalized, but flee prior to the issuance of a final order of deportation, may continue to  collect Social Security benefits. The Social Security Administration (SSA) and the Department of  Justice staff have drafted corrective legislation. Such legislation should go forward without delay.
column5: The text consists of factual material related to proposed legislation and does not contain any privileged or confidential information. As such, it would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional, deliberative, and privileged. ; ; There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA Exemption 5 criteria.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; While some groups have contended that such legislation could complicate the Government's ability to track down and successfully prosecute Nazi war criminals in this country, I find that contention difficult to accept. The federal government must pursue denaturalization and deportation against Nazi war criminals without any reference to whether or not they should receive Social Security benefits. Social Security benefits cannot, and should not, be used as a bargaining tool.
column5: The text consists of an opinion expressed by an individual and does not contain any factual material that would be protected under FOIA Exemption 5. This conclusion is supported by the case law established in Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." As the text does not fall under this category, it would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; The cruelest of ironies is the fact that, come August, SSA could be denying SSI benefits to legal immigrant Holocaust survivors while at the same time paying Social Security benefits to their Nazi tormentors.
column5: This text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The text is a statement of fact regarding the potential denial of SSI benefits to legal immigrant Holocaust survivors and the payment of Social Security benefits to their Nazi tormentors. As such, it does not fall under the scope of FOIA Exemption 5. ; ; There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; I would respectfully request that we meet to discuss this issue as soon as possible. Please contact my office at 202-358-6000 to set up an appointment
column5: The text is not protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not contain any information that falls under the category of privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. FOIA Exemption 5 protects from disclosure those documents that are normally privileged in the civil discovery process, such as attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and deliberative process privilege. However, the text above is a simple request for a meeting and does not contain any privileged information. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are normally privileged in the civil discovery process. Additionally, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. Since the text above does not contain any deliberative or predecisional information, it would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Sincerely, John J. Callahan Acting Commissioner Social Security Administration SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION WASHINGTON DC 20254
column5: The text provided is not protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not contain any privileged or confidential information. FOIA Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. However, the text provided is simply a signature block and does not contain any substantive information that would fall under this exemption. Therefore, it would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a general principle of FOIA law that information that is not privileged or confidential is subject to disclosure.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; FACT SHEET.   SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS AND NAZI WAR CRIMINALS
column5: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not contain any privileged or confidential information. The information provided is a matter of public record and does not involve any deliberative process or policy-making. As such, it is not subject to any exemption under FOIA.; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that FOIA Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. Similarly, in National Labor Relations Board v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are part of the agency's decision-making process and that would be privileged from discovery in civil litigation. Since the information in the fact sheet does not involve any deliberative process or policy-making, it would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Current Law and Policy • Current policy is to remove Nazi war criminals from the U.S. and to deny them Social Security benefits. There is, however, a loophole under current law.
column5: The text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making by a government agency. It simply states the current law and policy regarding the removal of Nazi war criminals from the U.S. and the denial of Social Security benefits to them, as well as a loophole in the law. This information is purely factual and does not involve any internal government communications or decision-making processes that would be protected under Exemption 5.; ; There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion as it is a well-established principle that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that involve the deliberative process of a government agency. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, and not to purely factual information.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; • Since the 1980's, the law has provided that Social Security benefits must be cut off when a final order of deportation is issued against an individual because that individual engaged in Nazi persecution or genocide. This provision of Social Security law is specifically for Nazi war criminals and provides for an earlier cut off than for other deportees, whose benefits are not cut off until they are actually deported.
column5: The factual material provided in the text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any deliberative process or policy-making discussions. The information provided is a straightforward explanation of a provision in Social Security law that applies to a specific group of individuals. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. The information provided in the text does not meet this standard and therefore would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; • Of the 31 living Nazi war criminals who were eligible for Social Security benefits and who have left the United States, only 10 have lost benefits because of the Nazi war criminal provision in current Social Security law. SSA found other grounds to cut off benefits to two additional Nazi war criminals, but they could return to the Social Security rolls.
column5: The factual material in the text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve inter-agency or intra-agency communications, deliberations, or recommendations. Rather, it is a report of factual information related to the administration of Social Security benefits to Nazi war criminals. As such, it would likely be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA Exemption 5 language and purpose. However, courts have consistently held that Exemption 5 applies only to materials that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, and not to purely factual information or final agency actions. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that Exemption 5 did not apply to a final agency decision, even though it was based on internal agency deliberations and analysis. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. Circuit held that Exemption 5 did not apply to factual information contained in an agency report, even though the report was prepared for internal agency use and contained some deliberative material.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; • As of March 15, 1997, 18 Nazi war criminals (almost 2/3) were being paid Social Security benefits. In addition, I Nazi war criminal was eligible, but was temporarily not in pay status on March 15 because he was suspended based on the erroneous information that a final order of deportation had, in fact, been issued.
column5: The factual material in this text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The information is a straightforward statement of facts and statistics, which does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making. Therefore, it would not be exempt from disclosure under Exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. The court emphasized that the exemption is not intended to shield purely factual information or final agency actions from disclosure. Similarly, in Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), the court held that Exemption 5 does not apply to factual material that is not part of a deliberative process. Therefore, the factual material in the text would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; • These individuals escaped the Nazi war criminal provision in current Social Security law because DOJ did not, or could not, get a final order of deportation. Some of these individuals fled before DOJ could act. Others left without a final order of deportation after having reached settlement agreements with DOJ's Office of Special Investigations.
column5: The factual material in the text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve inter-agency or intra-agency communications or documents that are typically protected under this exemption. The information provided is factual in nature and does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making by a government agency. ; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), where the Supreme Court held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both "predecisional" and "deliberative." Similarly, in Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), the D.C. Circuit held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are "predecisional and deliberative, reflecting the give-and-take of the consultative process." Since the factual material in the text does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making, it would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; • The operation of current law results in the U.S. taxpayers subsidizing the retirement of many Nazi war criminals, contrary to the policy that they not receive Social Security benefits.

This type of information is generally considered to be public information and not subject to exemption under FOIA.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are "predecisional" or "deliberative" in nature, and not to documents that are purely factual or contain final agency decisions. Additionally, in Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), the court held that Exemption 5 does not protect purely factual information that is not part of the agency's decision-making process.

In this case, the information provided is not predecisional or deliberative, but rather a factual account of meetings and discussions between two agencies. Therefore, it would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Proposal  • DOJ and SSA propose that Social Security benefits be cut off when a federal court denaturalizes someone on the grounds that the person engaged in Nazi persecution. This is an earlier point in time than under current law. This proposal would cut off benefits of those who leave the U.S. before an order of deportation is issued, as well as those who attempt to stay in the U.S. by fighting an order of deportation.

Additionally, in National Wildlife Federation v. United States Forest Service, 861 F.3d 1104 (9th Cir. 2017), the court held that Exemption 5 does not apply to factual information that is not part of the government's decision-making process. column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; I held the meeting yesterday with the DOJ, SSA, Neal Sher, former head of DOJ's OSI and representing the American Gathering of Holocaust Survivors, and Doug Bloomfield, representing the World Jewish Congress & World Jewish Restitution Organization. Counsel's Office (Dawn), Public Liaison (Jay Footlik) and 0MB (Melinda Haskins & Richard Green) also attended.
column5: The text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not contain any privileged or deliberative information. The text simply describes who attended a meeting and their affiliations. There is no indication that any confidential or sensitive information was discussed. Therefore, this information would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as it is a general principle that factual information is not protected under FOIA Exemption 5. However, case law such as NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975) and EPA v. Mink (1973) have established that Exemption 5 applies to privileged and deliberative information, not factual information.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; In summary, Messrs. Sher and Bloomfield presented a passionate argument that SSA's proposal will hurt prosecutions of Nazi war criminals. They want the status quo left alone and for SSA not to introduce its legislative proposal. They presented the argument that I outlined for you earlier: They deeply believe that some judges will act more sympathetically toward old men who were Nazis if they can argue that not only is the government trying to strip them of their citizenship, but the government is also impoverishing them while they are trying to defend their rights during the judicial process. They think that a single bad outcome in a case could have farreaching implications for other cases. They admit that it is impossible to accurately predict what judges may in fact do, but they hold the view with absolute conviction that this will hurt prosecutions.
column5: The text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve inter-agency or intra-agency communications, deliberations, or documents. The text is a summary of a presentation made by Messrs. Sher and Bloomfield regarding their argument against SSA's proposal, and their belief that it will hurt prosecutions of Nazi war criminals. This information does not fall under the scope of Exemption 5 because it does not involve any privileged or confidential information that would be exempt from disclosure. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, and that factual information is not protected under this exemption. Additionally, Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), held that factual material that is not part of the agency's decision-making process is not protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Obviously, everyone in attendance agreed that we shared the objective of not wanting to do anything to compromise prosecutions of Nazis. SSA and DOJ explained how they engaged in interagency discussions to reach what they jointly view as a proposal that properly balances SSA's concern about "subsidizing the retirement of Nazis" with enforcement concerns. It is important to note that DOJ concedes that there remains some possible enforcement implications, but again, they believe that this proposal is an appropriate balancing of policy objectives.
column5: The text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any deliberative process or policy-making. The text merely describes a meeting where attendees discussed a proposal that balances policy objectives. As such, it does not fall under the scope of Exemption 5, which protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are part of the deliberative process of policy-making. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which held that factual material is not protected under Exemption 5 because it does not involve the deliberative process. Additionally, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that factual material that is not part of the deliberative process is not protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; In my follow-up with the White House attendees at the meeting, we agree that the specific enforcement concern depends on predictions on what judges may or may not do and therefore does not sound fully compelling EXCEPT that it is impossible to ignore who is raising the concern. These individuals are representatives of those who are the most concerned about and the most effected by this proposal. It gains us very little to close this SSA loophole if taking that action is decried in the strongest possible terms by the victims of those war criminals as undermining their prosecutions.
column5: The text does not consist of factual material that would be protected under FOIA Exemption 5. FOIA Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The text does not fall under this exemption because it does not involve inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The text is a follow-up communication between the author and White House attendees at a meeting. Additionally, the text does not contain any privileged or confidential information that would be protected under FOIA Exemption 5. Therefore, the text would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of FOIA Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; And make no mistake, Messrs. Sher and Bloomfield were absolutely clear that they and their organizations would protest vociforously. They would protest in the media, and they would protest in Congress. They would make sure that it is known that the President has introduced legislation that would compromise the prosecutions of Nazis.

This type of factual material is generally not protected under Exemption 5. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that "purely factual material" is not protected under Exemption 5. Similarly, in Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 F.3d 607, 617 (D.C. Cir. 1997), the court held that "factual material that does not reveal the deliberative process" is not protected under Exemption 5. Therefore, the text would not be exempt from disclosure under FOIA Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; On the other hand, they said that if SSA is criticized for making such payments they would engage in whatever steps were necessary to explain to the public, to Members of Congress, and to the media that SSA's policies were sound and that anyone promoting an alternative view would be hurting prosecutions. There is already at least one critical article that has appeared (St. Petersburg Times) and SSA has been contacted by a Tampa CBS affiliate for comment. I think that we can anticipate other critical pieces, and it may be picked up by the national press. Cong. Bunning (R-Ky), chair of the Ways and Means Social Security Subcommittee has requested information about the St. Petersburg story.

This is factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are deliberative in nature and would harm the decision-making process if disclosed. The discussions and predictions do not involve any deliberative process or policy-making, but rather relate to potential public relations issues. Therefore, this material would not be exempt from disclosure under FOIA Exemption 5. There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA exemption.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Given the foregoing considerations, I think that this is a very difficult issue, but I have to recommend to you that we provide guidance to SSA that the proposal should not go forward, Normally, I would give quite a bit of deference to Justice and SSA for the product of a solid interagency process. Nobody wants to provide benefits to Nazis, ESPECIALLY when some of their victims who are legal immigrants may face benefit cut-offs, but we cannot ignore the absolute conviction of those who we heard from who represent the victims when they say that the President will hinder the prosecutions of Nazis with this proposal.

Cir. 1980), which held that "purely factual material" is not protected under Exemption 5. Additionally, Public Citizen v. Office of Management and Budget, 598 F.3d 865 (D.C. Cir. 2010), held that "factual material that is severable from deliberative material" is not protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Of the 31 living Nazi war criminal who were eligible for benefits and who have left the United  States, only 10 have lost benefits because of the Nazi war criminal provision in current Social Security law. As of March 15, 1997, 18 Nazi war criminals almost (2/3) were being paid Social Security benefits. SSA found other grounds to cut off benefits to two additional Nazi war criminals, but they could return to the Social Security roles and the pay status of another one is temporarily suspended.
column5: This text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The information provided is a straightforward report of the number of Nazi war criminals who have lost or retained their Social Security benefits. There is no indication that this information was obtained through any confidential communication or deliberation between government agencies. Therefore, it would not be exempt from disclosure under FOIA Exemption 5.; ; Case law: In Milner v. Department of Navy (2011), the Supreme Court held that FOIA Exemption 2, which protects from disclosure information related to internal personnel rules and practices, does not apply to records that are not related to such rules and practices. The Court emphasized that FOIA exemptions must be narrowly construed and that agencies cannot rely on them to withhold information that does not fall within their scope. Similarly, in Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. Department of Justice (2016), the D.C. Circuit held that FOIA Exemption 5 does not protect records that do not involve privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process of government agencies, not to shield factual information from disclosure.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Stephen C. Warnath 04/16/97 05:18:53 Record Type: Record To: Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP cc: Subject: Re: SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals ~
column5: The text does not contain any information that would be protected under FOIA Exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The text is a simple email exchange between two individuals discussing a topic of public interest (SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals). As such, it does not contain any privileged or confidential information that would be exempt from disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion, as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA Exemption 5 criteria.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; There is not a drop-dead deadline to drop a legislative proposal. However, the urgency of deciding  arises because the subcommittee Chairman & staff have been asking SSA as recently as  yesterday where they are on solving the problem of Nazi's getting paid. SSA has been putting them off saying that they are continuing to work on the issue. There is a technical mark-up, but this proposal doesn't have to be a technical (in fact it may not be eligible to be a technical). It could be offered later as a stand-alone (or alternatively a member of Congress could offer a bill and we could support that if we chose to) so the 23rd is not magical, but SSA is feeling pressure to get back to the subcommittee Chair fairly promptly.
column5: The text consists of factual material related to the internal workings of the Social Security Administration (SSA) and its interactions with a subcommittee of Congress. This type of information would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5, which covers inter- or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The text does not contain any opinions, recommendations, or policy proposals that would be protected under Exemption 5. Therefore, it would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as it is a general principle of FOIA law that factual material is not protected under Exemption 5. However, courts have consistently held that Exemption 5 applies only to materials that are both pre-decisional and deliberative, and that purely factual information is not protected. For example, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that "factual material is not exempt from disclosure under Exemption 5, regardless of whether it is contained in predecisional or deliberative documents."

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Also pressing is a media inquiry from the Tampa CBS affiliate that SSA has also been holding off for awhile. They want SSA to tell them what it's doing about the problem. SSA anticipates that this may be the beginnning of a lot of bad press about how it provides money for the retirement of Nazis.
column5: The text consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not involve any privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communication. The information is related to a media inquiry from a CBS affiliate regarding the Social Security Administration's response to the issue of providing money for the retirement of Nazis. This information is not protected by Exemption 5 because it does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making by the agency. ; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that Exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. The information in the text does not meet this standard and therefore would not be protected under Exemption 5.

column4: The text below consists of factual material that would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5.  Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; This is a no-win situation. We are either going to be criticized for paying retirement to Nazis or we will be criticized because at least several major Jewish organizations will charge us with compromising enforcement. There is going to be critical press whatever the decision is. The straight policy call is probably that we should be able to rely upon the Department of Justice to determine the appropriate enforcement assessment and what will or won't damage prosecutions. And DOJ says they have struck the right balance. However, I don't think that the policy determination can be completely divorced from an assessment of the political overlay on this issue.
column5: The text would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5 because it does not contain deliberative process material. The text is a discussion of policy considerations and political implications, but it does not involve the development or formulation of agency policy. As such, it would not be exempt from disclosure under Exemption 5. ; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that "purely factual material" is not protected under Exemption 5. Additionally, Public Citizen Health Research Group v. FDA, 704 F.2d 1280, 1290 (D.C. Cir. 1983), held that "statements of fact" are not protected under Exemption 5.

Explain why and cite any case law that supports this conclusion.; ; Let me know how you want to proceed or if I can get you some more information. If you think it would be helpful, I could set up a meeting between these gentlemen and you (and whoever else you think should be invited) so that you can guage this directly for yourself.
column5: The text does not contain any factual material that would be protected under FOIA Exemption 5. FOIA Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are privileged and would not be available to a party other than the agency in litigation with the agency. However, the text does not contain any such material. It is merely a communication between individuals discussing the possibility of a meeting. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA Exemption 5. There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the exemption.
